polished_script:
HOOK: Agents closing $2 billion in luxury deals send one email after every conversation. [ON-SCREEN: $2B+ luxury agents]

BRAND INTRO: "This is D.J. Paris with Keeping It Real Podcast, and this is your agent tip of the day."

SETUP: You just had a great showing. Client seemed interested, talked next steps, maybe even threw out a number. You're feeling good. Then three days later they're telling you something completely different than what you remember discussing. Sound familiar? [ON-SCREEN: "I thought you said..."]
[15-SEC RE-HOOK]: Here's what separates the pros from everyone else.

INSIGHT: Jill Preschel spent years in boardrooms with private equity partners and learned this the hard way: if you don't document it, it never happened. [ON-SCREEN: "If you don't document it, it never happened"] Her habit after every single conversation — client calls, showings, negotiations — she sends one email. Not long, just three things: what we discussed, what we agreed on, next steps. [ON-SCREEN: 1. Discussed 2. Agreed 3. Next steps] She learned this sitting across from capital partners who'd conveniently forget what they agreed to in meetings. The email isn't rude — it's a receipt. [ON-SCREEN: The email is a receipt]

REFRAME: This eliminates the "I thought you said" arguments, keeps you in control of the narrative, and makes you look like the one professional in a sea of amateurs. You can literally do this today — thirty seconds to write, but it's the difference between being remembered and being forgotten.

CTA: "Are you sending summary emails after your conversations — yes or no?"

CLOSE: "See you next time."

---

CAPTION: The $2B agents send this one email after every conversation. Most don't. Here's why you should start today.

HASHTAGS: #RealEstate #RealEstateAgent #RealEstateTips #LuxuryRealEstate #RealEstateSuccess

SHAREABLE_MOMENT: "If you don't document it, it never happened."

PERFORMANCE_NOTES: 
1. HOOK delivery: Sharp emphasis on "$2 billion" — let that number land before continuing
2. INSIGHT pacing: Slow down on "it's a receipt" — this is the key reframe moment
3. Eye contact: Direct camera contact during "You can literally do this today" for personal connection
